The upper line is written above the ruling.

handDesc.handNote: The handwriting is characterized by slender, tall and upright letters.

list.item:
f. 128rb: Donation note.
The note is written in red by the same hand that inserted the names of the donor and other persons in erasures. Däğğazmač Säba Gadǝs (sic for Subagadis, Säbagadis), called also by his baptismal name Za-Manfas Qǝddus, is mentioned as the buyer and donor of the Ms.

- Many omissions and/or corrections are written interlineally, sometimes in the main hand, sometimes in a secondary hand: e.g., fols. 7ra, 8vb, 10ra, 21va, 27vb, 28vb, 34rab, 39rab, 40rab, 40vb, 41vb, 62ra, 83va, 86va, 91vb, 110ra, 117ra, 118vab. - Immediate corrections are indicated by series of red dots around the incorrect letter: 25va, 39va, 76vb, 98rb, 126ra. - Occasionally words or parts of a word are crossed out: e.g., fols. 14ra, 43vb, 60va. - A few erasures (immediate corrections?) marked with thin parallel lines: e.g., fols. 28ra, 37rb, 38ra, 52va, 84rb, 89rb, 89vb, 90rb, 103rb; one marked with a simple ornamental band: fol. 41va. - Tamallas-sign (in the shape of +) indicating the place where the omission, written in the upper margin, belong: fol. 80ra. - Stamp of the church or donor: fols. 5r, 23v, 25v, 48v, 76v, 102v, 109r, 121r, 128r. - The name of the church is written in red felt-tip pen: fol. 1r. - Pen trial: fol. 1r.

binding.decoNote: Two wooden boards covered with reddish-brown tooled leather (for the most part hidden under the secondary textile cover). Two pairs of sewing stations.
Blind tooled ornament on the reddish-brown leather cover (at least 3 tools were used: single line fillet, triple line fillet and double circle).

decoDesc.decoNote: Nomina sacra; name of the protagonist; names of the donor and other persons; a few lines on the incipit page and of the sections of the text; incipit of its subsections; the word salām "salutation"; the word ba-ʾǝnta "about" on fol. 90va; elements of the punctuation signs and of the text dividers; elements of Ethiopic numerals.

origin.origDate: 18th cent. (?) The replacement of the name of the original donor by that of Za-Manfas Qǝddus (däğğazmač Subagadis, 1770-1831) hints that the Ms. was written not later than in early 19th cent.

person.persName: The name of the original donor has been erased throughout the Ms., but can be deciphered on fol. 98ra as Ḫayla Śǝllāse. The name was mostly replaced by a secondary hand with that of Za-Manfas Qǝddus, the baptismal name of däğğazmač Subagadis (1770-1831), who is also mentioned as the donor in Additio 1. Other names added later are: Walda Lǝʿul (fols. 33ra, 85vb, 114rb, 119ra, 125vb), Tasfā Māryām (fols. 113va, 118va, 127va), Gabra Ṣadǝq (fol. 113va), Walda Mikāʾel (fols. 114vb, 119rb) and Walda Gabrǝʾel (fol. 125vb).
